sect1.title: 포맷
sect1.para: PHP 매뉴얼은 여러 종류의 포맷으로 제공되고 있다. 이 포맷들은 두가지 그룹으로 나눌수 있는데, 다음과 같다: 온라인상에서 읽을수 있는 포맷, 다운로드될수 있는 패키지.

note.para: 이 매뉴얼을 출력한 형태로 만들수 있으나, 이렇게 하는것을 추천하지 않는다. 왜냐하면, 이런 출력물은 최신판에서 매우 빨리 뒤쳐질것이기 때문이다.

sect1.para: 온라인 상의 &url.php;과 그외 여러 미러사이트를 통해서 이 매뉴얼을 볼 수 있다. 빠른 속도를 위해서는 접속지역과 가장 가까운 미러사이트에 접속해야 할것이다. 이 매뉴얼을 단순한(출력용) HTML 포맷이나 PHP 웹사이트 자체에 통합된 매뉴얼의 HTML 포맷으로도 볼수 있다.
대부분의 오프라인 포맷에 비해 온라인 매뉴얼의 장점은 user-contributed notes의 통합이다. 확실한 단점은 온라인 포맷의 매뉴얼을 보기 위해서 온라인상에 있어야 한다는 것이다.
몇가지의 오프라인 매뉴얼 포맷이 제공되며, 이중 가장 적합한 포맷은 사용중인 운영체제와 개인적인 독서 스타일에 달려있다. 그런 많은 매뉴얼들이 어떻게 생성되는지 알기 위해서는 이 부록의 'How we generate the formats' 섹션을 참고한다.
이 매뉴얼 포맷중 가장 운영체제간 호환성이 높은것은 HTML과 단순-텍스트 버전이다. HTML 포맷은 단일의 HTML 파일과 섹션 파일들로 구성된 패키지로 제공된다. (각 섹션은 몇천개의 파일 묶음으로 되어있다) HTML과 단순텍스트 포맷은 bzip2 아카이브를 이용하여 압축된 타(tar)파일로 제공된다.
또다른 호환성 높고 가장 일반적인 포맷이며 가장 출력하기 적합한 포맷이 PDF (어도브 아크로뱃이라고 하기도 함)이다. 이 포맷을 다운로드하고 출력 버튼을 누르기 전에, 이 매뉴얼이 거의 2000 페이지 가량된다는 것과 지속적으로 개정된다는 것을 명심해야 할것이다.

note.para: PDF 포맷 파일을 볼수 있도록 하는 프로그램을 아직 설치하지 않았다면, Adobe Acrobat Reader을 다운로드해야 할것이다.

sect1.para: 팜(Palm) 호환 핸드헬드 사용자라면, 팜 문서와 아이실로(iSilo) 포맷이 이 플랫폼에 가장 적합하다. 통근중에 이 핸드헬드를 갖고다니면서 DOC이나 iSilo 리더를 사용하여 PHP 지식을 연마할수 있다. 또는 퀵 레퍼런스로 이 포맷을 사용할수있다.
윈도우 플랫폼을 위해 이 매뉴얼을 윈도우 HTML 헬프 버전으로 제공된다. 이 버전은 윈도우 HTML 헬프 응용프로그램에서 사용하는 HTML 포맷으로 구성되며, 문서전체 검색과 전체 인덱스, 북마크도 제공한다. 많이 사용되는 윈도우의 PHP 개발 환경은 쉬운 접근을 위해 이 문서 형태도 함께 제공된다.

sect1.title: user notes에 관하여
sect1.para: user-contributed notes는 이 매뉴얼 개발에 있어서 매우 중요한 역할을 담당하고 있다. 브라우저상에서 매뉴얼의 독자에게 예제코드, 경고, 좀더 자세한 설명을 제공해줌으로써, 매뉴얼의 주요 텍스트안에 피드백을 함께 추가시킬수 있다. 이런 notes가 통합되어 않으면, 온라인이나 일부 오프라인 포맷에서 제출폼이 보일것이다.

note.para: The user-contributed notes are not moderated before they appear online, so the quality of the writing or code examples, and even the veracity of the contribution, cannot be guaranteed. (Not that there is any guarantee of the quality or accuracy of the manual text itself.)

For the purposes of license coverage the user-contributed notes are considered part of the PHP manual, and are therefore covered by the same license that covers this documentation (GPL at the moment). For more details see the Manual's Copyright page.

sect1.title: How to read a function definition (prototype)
sect1.para: Each function is documented for quick reference, knowing how to read and understand the manual will make using PHP much easier. Rather than relying on examples or cut/paste, you want to know how to read function definitions (prototypes). Let's begin:

note.title: Prerequisite: Basic understanding of types
note.para: Although PHP is a loosly typed language, it's important to have a basic understanding of types as they have important meaning.

para.screen:
strlen
(PHP 3, PHP 4 >= 4.0.0) strlen -- Get string length
Description int strlen ( string str )
Returns the length of string.

row.entry: strlen() has been around in both all of PHP 3 and PHP 4
Type of value this function returns, which is an integer (i.e. The length of a string is measured in numbers).
The first (and in this case the only) parameter/argument for the function strlen() is named str, and it's a string.

sect1.para: We could rewrite the above function definition in a generic way:

para.screen: returned type function name ( parameter type parameter name )

sect1.para: Many functions take on multiple parameters, such as in_array. It's prototype is as follows:

para.screen: bool in_array ( mixed needle, array haystack [, bool strict])

sect1.para: What does this mean? in_array() returns a boolean value, &true; on success (the needle was found in the haystack) or &false; on failure (the needle was not found in the haystack). The first parameter is named needle and it can be many different types, so we call it "mixed". This mixed needle (what we're looking for) can either be a scalar value (string, integer, or float), or an array. haystack (the array we're searching in) is the second parameter. The third optional parameter is named strict. All optional parameters are seen in [ brackets ]. The manual states that the strict parameter defaults to boolean &false;. See the manual page on each function for details on how they work.

sect1.title: PHP versions documented in this manual
sect1.para: This documentation contains information about PHP 4, with some added migration and compatibility notes regarding PHP 3. Behaviour, parameter, return value and other changes between different PHP versions are documented in notes and inline text in the manual.

You may find documentation pieces for the CVS version of PHP, which always means the very latest development version available through the CVS version handling system. If you are not a developer of PHP itself, and you are not keen on using the very latest development version of PHP, features marked with the "available in CVS" wording are not accessible to you. Though these features will probably be available in the next stable version of PHP. If you would like to download the CVS version, see the anonymous CVS access page.

You may also encounter documentation for a PHP version which is not released (something like PHP 5.0.0 as the latest stable version is 4.3.0). Most of the time, this is not an error in the documentation. Explanation is often added for features not available in the current PHP release, but will be available in a known future PHP version.

sect1.title: How to find more information about PHP
sect1.para: This manual does not attempt to provide instruction about general programming practices. If you are a first-time, or even just a beginning, programmer, you may find it difficult to learn how to program in PHP using just this manual. You may want to seek out a text more oriented towards beginners. You can find a list of PHP-related books at &url.php.books;.

There are a number of active mailing lists for discussion of all aspects of programming with PHP. If you find yourself stuck on a problem for which you can't find your own solution, you may be able to get help from someone on these lists. You can find a list of the mailing lists at &url.php.support;, as well as links to the mailing list archives and other online support resources. Furthermore, at &url.php.links; there is a list of websites devoted to PHP articles, forums, and code galleries.

sect1.title: How to help improve the documentation
sect1.para: There are three ways you can help to improve this documentation.

If you find errors in this manual, in any language, please report them using the bug system at &url.php.bugs;. Classify the bug as "Documentation Problem". You can also submit problems related to specific manual formats here.

note.para: Please don't abuse the bug system by submitting requests for help. Use the mailing lists or community sites mentioned earlier, instead.

sect1.para: By contributing notes, you can provide additional examples, caveats, and clarifications for other readers. But do not submit bug reports using the annotation system please. You can read more about annotations in the 'About user notes' section of this appendix.

If you know English and some foreign language, you may also help out in the translations. If you would like to start a new translation, or help in a translation project, please read &url.php.dochowto;.

sect1.title: How we generate the formats
sect1.para: This manual is written in XML using the DocBook XML DTD, using DSSSL (Document Style and Semantics Specification Language) for formatting, and experimentally the XSLT (Extensible Stylesheet Language Transformations) for maintenance and formatting.

Using XML as a source format gives us the ability to generate many output formats from the source files, while only maintaining one source document for all formats. The tools used for formatting HTML and TeX versions are Jade, written by James Clark and The Modular DocBook Stylesheets written by Norman Walsh. We use Microsoft HTML Help Workshop to generate the Windows HTML Help format of the manual, and of course PHP itself to do some additional conversions and formatting.

You can download the manual in various languages and formats, including plain text, plain HTML, PDF, PalmPilot DOC, PalmPilot iSilo and Windows HTML Help, from &url.php.docs;. The manuals are updated automatically as the text is updated.
You can find more information about downloading the XML source code of this documentation at &url.php.cvs;. The documentation is stored in the phpdoc module.

sect1.title: Translations
sect1.para: The PHP manual is not only available in various formats, it is also available in various languages. The text of the manual is first written in english, then teams of people across the world take care of translating it to their native language. If a translation for a specified function or chapter has not yet been made, the build system of the manual falls back to the english version of it.

Peoples involved in the translations start from the XML source code available from &url.php.cvs; and from it they translate to thier mother language. They do not use the HTML, the plain text, or the PDF version. It is the build system which takes care of the conversions from XML to human readable formats.

note.para: If you would like to help translating the documentation to your native language, please get in touch with the translation/documentation team subscribing to the phpdoc mailinglist: send an empty mail to &email.php.doc.subscribe;. The mailing list address is &email.php.doc;. State in the message that you are interested in translating the manual to a language and someone will get back to you, helping you start a new language translation or reach the already active documentation team for your language.

sect1.para: At the moment the manual is available, partly or not, in the following languages: Brazilian Portuguese, Chinese (Simplified), Chinese (Traditional), Czech, Dutch, Finnish, French, German, Hebrew, Hungarian, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Polish, Romanian, Russian, Slovak, Slovenian, Spanish, Swedish, and Turkish.
They all can be downloaded here: &url.php.docs;.
